Thanks.  I added my remote interfaces to the excluded.properties file and
everything started working fine.  

-----Original Message-----
From: Scott Stirling [mailto:sstirling@...]
Sent: Monday, July 16, 2001 4:12 PM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] ClassCastException only using swing/awt ui


Interestingly, calls to javax.rmi.PortableRemoteObject are delegated to an
implementation of javax.rmi.CORBA.PortableRemoteObjectDelegate, which in
Sun's 1.3.1 JDK is com.sun.corba.se.internal.javax.rmi.PortableRemoteObject.
That doesn't explain anything -- I just thought it was just kinda
interesting how buried that reference was.

Anyway, this is another problem inherent to JUnit's Swingui's
TestCaseClassLoader architecture.  Similar to the LinkageErrors with JAXP
and the org.xml and org.w3c classes, but with a different result here.
We've seen it here with EJB lookups too, but we mostly use the Ant runner so
it's not usually a problem.

So why a ClassCastException when you narrow() in a TestCase?  

Here's John Pletka's test code:

Point point;
PointHome pointHome;

//The next line works in textui, but throws 
//ClassCastException in swingui
pointHome =
(PointHome)PortableRemoteObject.narrow(ctx.lookup("base/PointHome"),PointHom
e.class);

Recall that in Java 2 an object's class (aka "runtime type") is identified
in the JVM as <fully-qualified-classname;definingClassLoaderInstance> or
<C;L>.  That is, the defining loader is part of the runtime name identifying
that class (there's a subtle distinction in Java between 'class' and 'type'
I won't go into).  Also recall that the JVM will ask a class's defining
loader to load all unloaded classes referenced by the classes it loads.

My hypothesis (I just tested it here and proved it) is that the ctx.lookup()
returns an object that was loaded through the JVM's system classloader
(sun.misc.Launcher$AppClassLoader), but the PointHome.class type is loaded
by JUnit's TestCaseClassLoader.  In the narrow, the two fully qualified
class names are the same, but the defining classloaders for the two are
different so you get the exception because the JVM doesn't see them as being
the same <C;L> class/type.

The solution would be to exclude your EJB's interface classes from being
loaded by the JUnit custom class loader by adding them to the
excluded.properties in junit.jar.  Granted, not a very nice solution unless,
perhaps, it were easier to modify the exclusion list.  I hear in JUnit 4.0
that one idea is to make it easy to define exclusions in TestCases
themselves.

You can find out more about which loader loaded which class by doing this:

System.out.println(ctx.lookup("base/PointHome"));
System.out.println(PointHome.class.getClassLoader());

I bet you'll find when using the Swing UI that the PointHome type is defined
by the JUnit TestCaseClassLoader and the object returned from ctx.lookup()
was defined through the JVM's system class loader.  When using the textui
they'll both load through the system loader.

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia
